body:
## Types of graphs

There are five types of graph and four types of ggplot2 graph right now. More types will be updated.

Graph Type | name | Description
-----------|------|------------
Scatter plot | plot | 	
Bar plot | hist |	
Box and Whisker plot | box | 	
Line plot | lines |	
Pie plot | pie | no support in ggplot2

Here is a summary of what types of interactivity each plot supports:
LET'S SUMMARIZE WHAT TYPES OF INTERACTIVITY EACH PLOT TYPE SUPPORTS IN A TABLE.
Read more about [types of supported interactivity](http://bethetaedu.github.io/tutorial/interactivity) and [supported plotting options](http://bethetaedu.github.io/tutorial/options).

### 1. Scatter plot
 * [Scatter plot](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scatter_plot), display values for two variables for a set of data.
 * Regression (linear, loess) is enabled. The calculation for a regression line is done by the server side with R. (Shiny library is used here)
To draw basic scatter graph type:
```R
> RIGHT(plot(price ~ carat, diamonds, type="p"))
```
or you can make same graph using ggplot2 or qplot API
```R
> RIGHT(print(ggplot(diamonds, aes(carat, price)) + geom_point()))
```
If you want to use qplot function,
```R
> RIGHT(qplot(x=carat, y=price, data=diamonds, geom="point"))
```
![](http://thepotter.woobi.co.kr/img/scatter_diamonds.PNG)

### 2. Bar plot
 * [Bar plot](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bar_chart), rectangular bars with lengths proportional to the values.
To draw basic bar graph type:
```R
> RIGHT(hist(price, diamonds))
```
or
```R
> RIGHT(print(ggplot(diamonds, aes(price, fill = price)) + geom_bar()))
```
If you want to use qplot function,
```R
> RIGHT(qplot(x=price, fill=price, data=diamonds, geom="bar"))
```
![](http://thepotter.woobi.co.kr/img/bar_diamonds.PNG)

### 3. Box and Whisker plot
 * [Box and Whisker plot](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Box_plot), a convenient way of graphically depicting groups of numerical data through their quartiles.
To draw basic box and whisker graph type:
```R
> subArray <- diamonds[sample(1:nrow(diamonds), 1000, TRUE), ]
> RIGHT(boxplot(price ~ color, subArray))
```
or
```R
> subArray <- diamonds[sample(1:nrow(diamonds), 1000, TRUE), ]
> RIGHT(print(ggplot(subArray, aes(color, price)) + geom_boxplot()))
```
If you want to use qplot function,
```R
> subArray <- diamonds[sample(1:nrow(diamonds), 1000, TRUE), ]
> RIGHT(qplot(x=color, y=price, data=subArray, geom="boxplot"))
```
![](http://thepotter.woobi.co.kr/img/box_diamonds.PNG)

### 4. Line plot
 * [Line plot](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Line_chart), displays information as a series of data points connected by straight line segments.
To draw basic line graph type:
```R
> subArray <- diamonds[sample(1:nrow(diamonds), 1000, TRUE), ]
> RIGHT(plot(price ~ carat, subArray, type= "l"))
```
or
```R
> subArray <- diamonds[sample(1:nrow(diamonds), 1000, TRUE), ]
> RIGHT(print(ggplot(subArray, aes(carat, price)) + geom_line()))
```
If you want to use qplot function,
```R
> subArray <- diamonds[sample(1:nrow(diamonds), 1000, TRUE), ]
> RIGHT(qplot(x=carat, y=price, data=subArray, geom="line"))
```
![](http://thepotter.woobi.co.kr/img/line_diamonds.PNG)

### 5. Pie chart
 * [Pie chart](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pie_chart), circular chart divided into sectors, illustrating numerical proportion.
To draw basic pie graph type:
```R
> RIGHT(pie(color, diamonds))
```
There is no support using ggplot2 API to draw pie chart
![](http://thepotter.woobi.co.kr/img/pie_diamonds.PNG)
